DIV1.HEAD: TO MY HONOVRED friend, master Thomas May, vpon his Comedy, The Heire.
DIV1.L: THe Heire being borne, was in his tender age
Rockt in the Cradle of a priuate Stage,
Where lifted vp by many a willing hand,
The child doth from the first day fairely stand,
Since, hauing gathered strength, he dares preferre
His steps into the publicke Theater
The World: where he dispaires not but to find
A doome from men more able, but lesse kind.
I but his Vsher am, yet if my word
May passe, I dare be bound he will afford
Things must deserue a welcome, it well knowne
Such as best writers would haue wisht their owne.
You shall obserue his words in order meete,
And often stealing on, with equall feete
Slide into equall numbers, with such grace
As each word had beene moulded for that place.
You shall perceiue an amorous passion, spun
Into so smooth a web, as had the sunne,
When he pursu'd the swiftly flying Maid,
Courted her in such language she had staid,
A loue so well exprest must be the same,
The Author felt himselfe from his faire flame.
The whole plot doth like it selfe disclose
Through the fiue Acts, as doth a Looke, that goes
With letters, for till euery one be knowne,
The Lock's as fast as if you had found none.
And where his sportiue Muse doth draw a thred
Of mirth, chast Matrons may not blush to reade.

DIV1.HEAD: AN EXCELLENT COMEDY CALLED the Heire.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.P: My Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Hast thou divulg'd the newes
That my sonne dy'd at Athens.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.L: Yes my Lord,
With euery circumstance, the time, the place,
And manner of his death; that it is beleeu'd
And told for newes with as much confidence
As if twere writ in Gallobelgicus.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: That's well, that's very well, now Roscio
Followes my part, I must expresse a griefe
Not vsuall, not like a well left heire
For his dead father, or a lusty Widdow
For her old husband, must I counterfeit,
But in a deeper, a farre deeper straine
Weepe like a Father for his onely sonne,
Is not that hard to doe, ha, Roscio?

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: Oh no my Lord,
Not for your skill, has not your Lordship seene
A player personate Ieronimo?

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: By th'masse tis true, I haue seen the knaue paint griefe
In such a liuely colour, that for false
And acted passion he has drawne true teares
From the spectators eyes, Ladyes in the boxes
Kept time with sighes, and teares to his sad accents
As had he truely bin the new man he seemd.
Well then Ile neere dispaire; but tell me thou
Thou that hast still beene priuy to my bosome,
How will this proiect take?

SP.SPEAKER: Rosc.
SP.L: Rarely my Lord,
hen now my thinkes, I see your Lordships house
with suitors of the noblest ranke,
And my yong Lady your supposed Heire
more with woing then the Grecian Queene
In the long absence of her wandring Lord.
Theres not a ruinous nobility
In all this kingdome, but conceiues a hope
Now to ebuild his fortunes on this match.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Those are not they I looke for, no, my ne
Are spread for other game, the rich and greedy
Those that haue wealth enough, yet gape for more
They are for me,

SP.SPEAKER: Ros
SP.L: Others will come my Lord,
All sorts of fish will presse vpon your nets,
Then in your Lordships wisedome it must lie
To cull the great ones, and reiect the frie.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Nay feare not that, there's none shall haue accesse
To see my daughter, or to speake to her,
But such as I approue, and ayme to catch.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: The iest will be, my Lord, when you shall see
How your aspiring suitors will put on
The face of greatnesse, and bely their fortunes
Consume themselues in shew, wasting like Merchants
Their present wealth in rigging a fayre ship
For some ill venture de voyage, that vndoes vm.
Here comes a youth with letters from the Court,
Bought of some fauourite at such a price
As will for euer sinke him, yet alas
all's to no purpose, he must loose the prize.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: This was a iest well thought of, the conceit
Will feed me fat, with sport that it shall make,
Besides the large aduentures it brings home
Vnto my daughter. How now. enter seruant

SP.P: My Lord, Count Virro is come to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Conduct him in; So, so, it takes already
See Roscio see, this is the very man
My proiect aymd at, the rich Count that knowe
No end of his large wealth, yet gapes for more
There was no other loadstone could attract
His Iron heart, for could beauty haue mou'd him,
Nature has beene no niggard to my girle,
But I must to my griefe, here comes the Count.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.P: Is your Lord a sleepe?

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: No Sir.
I thinke not, my Lord, Count Virro.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋir.
SP.P: How doe you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: I do intreat your Lordship pardon, my griefe and some want of sleepe haue made mee at this time vn∣mannerly, not fit to entertaine guests of your worth.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir
SP.P: Alas Sir I know your griefe.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.P: Twas that that fetcht you hither. aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: Y'haue lost a worthy and a hopefull sonne,
But heauen that alwayes giues, will sometimes take
And that the best, there is no balsome left vs
To cure such wounds as these but patience,
There's no disputing with the acts of heauen,
But if there were, in what could you accuse
Those powers that else haue beene so liberall to you,
And left you yet one comfort in your age:
A faire and vertuous daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: Now it beginnes.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.P: Your blood is not extinct, nor your age childlesse, from that fayre branch thats left may come much fruite to glad posteritie, thinke on that my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Nay heauen forbid I should repine at what the
Iustice of those powers ordaine, it has pleasd
Them to confine my care onely to one, and to
See her well bestowd is all the comfort I now
Must looke for, but if it had pleasd heauen that
My sonne, ah my Eugenio. he weepes.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.P: Alas good Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: Fore heauen he does it rarely.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir,
SP.L: But Sir, remember your selfe, remember your
Daughter, let not your griefe for the dead make
You forget the liuing, whose hopes, and fortunes
Depend vpon your safety.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: Oh my good Lord, you neuer had a soone.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.L: Vnlesse they were bastards, and for them no
Doubt but he has done as other Lords do.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: And therefore cannot tell what tis to loose
A sonne, a good sonne, and an onely sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: I would, my Lord, I could as well redresse
As I can take compassion of your griefe
You should soone finde an ease.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: Pray Pardon me my Lord, if I forget my selfe to∣ward you at this time, if it please you visite my house ofter you shall be welcome.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.P: You would faine sleepe my Lord, Ile take my leaue auen send you comfort, I shall make bold shortly to visite you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: You shall be wondrous welcome,
Wait on my Lord out there. exit Virr.
So now he's gone, how thinkst thou Roscio,
Will not this Gudgeon bite?

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: No doubt my Lord,
So faire a bayte would catch a cunning fish.
And such a one is he, he euer lou'd
The beauty of my girle, but thats not it
Can draw the earth bred thoughts of his grosse soule
Gold is the God of his idolatry,
hope of which Ile feed him, till at length
I make him fasten, and Ixion like
For his lou'd Iuno graspe an empty clowd.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: How stands my yong Lady affected to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: There's all the difficulty, we must win her to loue , I doubt the peeuish Gyrle will thinke him too , he's well neere threescore: in this businesse I must eaue somewhat to thy wit and care, prayse him beyond all measure.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: Your Lordship euer found me trusty.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: If thou effect it, I will make thee happy. exeunt

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Eugenios sister then is the rich heire
By his decease.

SP.SPEAKER: Cler.
SP.L: Yes, and the faire one too,
She needs no glosse that fortune can set on her,
Her beauty of it selfe were prize enough
To make a king turne begger for.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Hoy day,
What in loue Clerimont, I lay my life tis so,
Thou couldst not praise her with such passion else.

SP.SPEAKER: Cler.
SP.L: I know not, but I slept well enough last night,
But if thou sawst her once, I would not giue
A farthing for thy life, I tell thee Philocles
One fight of her would make thee cry, ay me,
Sigh, and looke pale, me thinkes I do imagine
How like an Idolatrous louer thou wouldst looke
Through the eye-lids, know no body.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Tis very well, but how did your worship scape
Youe haue seene her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cler.
SP.L: True, but I haue an
Antidote, and I can teach it thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: When
I haue need on't Ile desire it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cler.
SP.L: And twill
Be worth thy learning, when thou shalt see the
Tyranny of that same seuruy boy, and what fooles
He makes of vs; shall I describe the beast?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: What beast?

SP.SPEAKER: Cler.
SP.P: A louer.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cler.
SP.P: Then to be briefe, I will passe ouer the opinion of your ancient fathers, as likewise those strange Loues spo∣ken of in the Authenticke histories of chiualrie Amadis du Gaule, Parismus, the Knight of the Sunne, or the witty Knight Don Quixot de la Manca, where those braue men, neither Enchantments, Gyants, Wind-mils, nor flockes of sheepe could vanquish, are made the trophyes of tryum∣phing loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Prithee come to the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Cler.
SP.P:
Neither will I mention the complaints of Sir Guy for the faire Phelis, nor the trauels of Parismus for the loue of the beautious Laurana, nor lastly, the most sad pennance of the ingenious knight Don Quixot vpon the mountains of Scienna Morenna, mooud by the vniust disdaine of the Lady Dulcinea del Toboso, or our moderne Authors, I
will not so much as name them, no not that excellent treatise of Tullies Loue, written by the Master of Art.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: I would thou wouldest passe ouer this passing o∣uer of Authors, and speake thine owne iudgement.

SP.SPEAKER: Cler.
SP.P: Why then to be briefe, I thinke a Louer lookes like an Asse.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: I can describe him better then so my selfe, he lookes like a man that had sitten vp at Cards all night, or a stale Drunkard wakened in the middest of his sleepe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cler.
SP.P: But Philocles, I would not haue thee see this La∣dy, she has a bewitching looke.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: How darest thou venture man, what strange medi∣cine hast thou found, Ouid neere taught it thee, I doubt I guesse thy remedy, for loue, goe to a bawdy house or so, ist not?

SP.SPEAKER: Cler.
SP.P: Faith, and that's a good way I can tell you, we yonger brothers are beholding to it, alas wee must not fall in loue and choose whom wee like best, wee haue no Ioyntures for vm, as you blest heires can haue.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Well I haue found you Sir, and prithee tell me, how got'st thou Wenches?

SP.SPEAKER: Cler.
SP.P: Why I can want no Panders, I lye in the Consta∣bles house.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: And there you may whoore by authority,
But Clerimont, I doubt this Parragon
That thou so praisest, is some il fauoured Wench
Whom thou wouldst haue me laugh at for commending.

SP.SPEAKER: Cler.
SP.L: By heauen I spoke in earnest, trust your eyes,
Ile shew you her.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: How canst thou doe it?
Thou know'st this Ladies father is to mine
A deadly enemy, nor is his house,
Open to any of our kindred.

SP.SPEAKER: Cler.
SP.L: That's no matter,
My lodging's the next doore to this Lords house,
And my backe Window lookes into his Garden,
There euery morning faire Leucothoe,
(For so I heare her nam'd) walking alone,
To please her senses makes Aurora blush,
To see on brighter then her appeare.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Well I will see her the▪ Exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Franc.
SP.L: Yet for her sake be aduised better Sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Impudent Rascall, canst looke me i'th face,
And know how thou hast wrong'd me, thou hast
Dishonoured my Daughter, made a whoore on her.

SP.SPEAKER: Franc.
SP.L: Gentle Sir,
The wrong my loue has made to your faire Daughter
Tis now too late to wish vndone againe,
But if you please, it may be yet clos'd vp
Without dishonour, I will marry her.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Marry her, she has a hot catch of that, marry a Begger, what Iointure canst thou make her?

SP.SPEAKER: Franc.
SP.L: Sir I am poore I must confesse,
Fortune has blest you better, but I sweare
By all things that can bind, twas not your wealth
Was the foundation of my true built loue,
It was her single vncompounded selfe,
Her selfe without addition that I lou'd,
Which shall for euer in my sight outweigh
All other womens fortunes, and themselues,
And were I great, as great as I could wish
My selfe for her aduancement, no such barre
As Fortunes inequality should stand
Betwixt our loues.

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.P: Good Father heare me.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Dost thou not blush to call me father, Strumpet Ile make thee an example.

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.L: But heare me
Sir, my shame will be your owne.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: No more I say, Francisco leaue my house, I charge You come not heere.

SP.SPEAKER: Franc.
SP.L: I must obey and will,
Deare Luce be constant.

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
SP.L: Till death

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Here's a fine wedding towards, the
Bridegroome when he comes for his bride,
Shall find her great with child by another man,
Passion a me minion, how haue you hid it so long?

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Fearing your anger Sit, I striu'd to hide it.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Hide it one day more then, or be damn'd,
Hide it till Shallow be married to thee,
And then let him do his worst.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: Sir I should too much wrong him.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Wrong him, there bee great Ladies haue done the like, tis no newes to see a bride with childe.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: Good Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Then be wise, lay the child to him, he's a rich man, tother's a beggar.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: I dare not Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Do it I say, and he shall father it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: He knowes he neuer touch me Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Thats all one, lay it to him, weele out face him tis his: but harke, he is comming, I heare the Musicke, sweare thou wilt doe thy best to make him thinke tis his, sweare quickly.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: I doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Go step aside, and come when thy que is, thou shalt heare vs talke. Luce aside.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.P: Morrow Father.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Sonne bridegroome welcome, you haue beene lookt for here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.P: My Tayler a little disappointed me, but is my Bride ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Yes long ago, but you and I will talke a little, send in your Musicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.L: Go wait within, and tell me father, did she not
Thinke it long till I came.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank,
SP.L: I warrant
Her she did, she loues▪ you not a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.L: Nay that I dare sweare, she has giuen me many
Tasts of her affection.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: What before you
Were marryed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.L: I meane, in the way
Of honesty father.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Nay that I doubt,
Yong wits loue to be trying, and to say
Truth, I see not how a woman can deny a man
Of your youth and person vpon those tearmes,
Youle not be knowne ont now.

SP.SPEAKER: Shal.
SP.L: I haue kist
Her or so.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Come, come, I know you are no
Foole, I should thinke you a very Asse, nay I tell
You plainely, I should be loth to marry my
Daughter to you if I thought you had not tride
Her in so long acquaintance, but you haue tride
Her, and she poore soule could not deny you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.P: Ha ha hae.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Faith tell me sonne, tis but a
Merry question, she's yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.L: Vpon my
Virginity father.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Sweare not by that,
Ile nere beleeue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.L: Why then as I am
A Gentleman I neuer did it that I remember.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: That you remember, oh ist thereabouts.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Heele take it vpon him presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: You haue beene so familiar with her,
You haue forgot the times, but did you neuer
Come in halfe fudled, and then in a kinde humour,

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.P: Indeed I was wont to serue my mothers maide so when I came halfe foxt as you sayd, and then next mor∣ning I should laugh to my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Why there it goes, I thought to haue chid you sonne Shallow, I knew what you had done, tis too apparant, I would not haue people take notice of it pray God she hide her great belly as she goes to Church to day.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.P: Why father is she with child?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: As if you knew not that, fie, fie, leaue your dis∣sembling now.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.P: Sure it cannot be mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: How's this, you would not make my daugh∣ter a whore, would you? this is but to try if you can stirre my choller, your wits haue strange trickes, do things ouer night when you are merry, and then deny vm. But stay, here she comes alone, step aside, she shall not seevs,

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.L: Ah my deare Shallow, thou needst not haue made
Such hast, my heart thou knowest was firme enough
To thee, but I may blame my owne fond loue,
That could not deny thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Shal.
SP.L: She's with child indeed, it swels,

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: You would not beleeue me, tis a good wench,
She does it handsomely.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.L: But yet I know if
Thou hadst bin thy selfe, thou wouldst neere haue
Offered it, twas drinke that made thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Shal.
SP.L: Yes sure, I was drunke when I did it, for I had
Forgot it▪ I lay my life twill proue a girle
Because twas got in drinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Lu.
SP.P: I am ashamd to see any body.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Alas poore wretch, go comfort her, Luce.

SP.SPEAKER: Shal.
SP.P: Sweet heart, nay neuer bee ashamd, I was a little too hasty, but Ile make thee amends, weele bee marryed presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Be cheery Luce, you were man and wife before, it wanted but the ceremony of the Church, and that shall be presently done.

SP.SPEAKER: Shal.
SP.P: I I, sweet heart, as soone as may be.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: But now I thinke ont sonne Shallow, your wed∣ding must not now be publicke, as we entended it.

SP.SPEAKER: Shal.
SP.P: Why so?

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Because I would not haue people take notice of this fault, weele go to Church, onely we three, the Mini∣ster and the Cleark, thats witnesses enough, so the time be∣ing vnknowne, people will thinke you were marryed be∣fore.

SP.SPEAKER: Shal.
SP.P: But will it stand with my worship to be married in priuate.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Yes, yes, the greatest do it, when they haue bene before hand, there is no other way to saue your bries credite.

SP.SPEAKER: Shal.
SP.P: Come lets about it presently.
This is closd vp beyond our wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.L: I am vndone, vnlesse, thy wit Francisco,
Can find some meanes to free me from this foole,
Who would haue thought the sot could be so grosse
To take vpon him what he neuer did,
To his owne shame, Ile send to my Francisco,
And I must loose no time, for I am dead,
If not deliuered from this loathed bed.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus secundus.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Philocles, Clerimont at the window.

SP.SPEAKER: Cler.
SP.L: SEE Philocles, yonders that happy shade,
That often vailes the faire Lucothoe,
And this her vsuall howre, sheele not be long,
Then thou shalt tell me, if so rare an obiect
Ere blest thine eyes before.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Well, I would see her once,
Wert but to try thy iudgement Cleremont.

SP.SPEAKER: Cler.
SP.L: And when thou doest, remember what I told thee,
I would not be so sicke, but soft looke to thy heart,
Yonder she comes, and thats her waiting woman.
SP.STAGE: Leucothoe and Psecas in the garden.
SP.L: Now gaze thy fill, speake man how likest thou her.

SP.SPEAKER: Psecas.
SP.P: Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: What flower was that
That thou wert telling such a story of
Last night to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pse.
SP.L: Tis call Narcissus Madam▪
It beares the name of that too beautious boy,
That lost himselfe by louing of himselfe,
Who viewing in afaire and cristall streame
Those lips that onely he could neuer kisse,
Dotes on the shadow, which to reach in vaine
Striuing, he drwones thus scorning all beside
For the loued shadow the fairer substance dyde.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: Fie fie, I like not these impossible tales,
A man to fall in loue with his owne shadow,
And died for loue, it is most ridiculous.

SP.SPEAKER: Pse.
SP.L: Madam I know not, I haue often seene
Both men and women court the looking glasse
With so much seeming contentation,
That I could thinke this true, nay weare it about vm
As louers do their Mistresse counterfeit.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: Thas not for loue, but to correct their beauties
And draw from others admiration,
For all the comfort that our faces giue
Vnto our selues is but reflection
Of that faire likeing that another takes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cler.
SP.L: I would we were a little neerer vm
We migh but heare what talke these wenches haue
When they are alone, I warrant some good stuffe.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Tis happinesse enough for me to see
The motion of her lips.

SP.SPEAKER: Cler.
SP.L: I aith ist there abouts.
Why Philocles, what lost already man,
Strooke dead with one poore glance, looke vp for shame
And tell me how thou likest my iudgement now,
Now thou doest see.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Ah Cleremont too well,
Too well I see what I shall neuer taste,
You Ladies beautie: she must needs be cruell
(Though her faire shape deny it) to the sonne
Of him that is her fathers enemy,
That, Cleremont, that fatall difference
Checkes my desire, and sinkes my rising hopes,
But loue's a torrent violent if stopt,
And I am desperately mad: I must
must be hers, or else I must not be.

SP.SPEAKER: Cler.
SP.L: Containe that passion that will else ouerwhelme
All vertue in you, all that is called man,
And should be yours, take my aduice my heart
My life to second you, let vs consult,
You may find time to speake to her and woe her.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: May, nay I will in spite of destinie,
women and faint hearted fooles complaine
In languishing dispayre, a manly loue
Dares shew it selfe and presse to his desires
Through thickest troopes of horid opposites,
Were there a thousand waking Dragons set
To keepe that golden fruit: I would attempt
To plucke and taste it, tis the danger crownes
A braue atchieuement: what if I should goe
And boldly wooe her in her fathers house
In spite enmity, what could they say?

SP.SPEAKER: Cle.
SP.L: Twere madnesse that not wisedome rash attempts
Betray the meanes, but neuer worke the end.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: She would not hate a man for louing her,
Or if she did, better be once deemed
Then liue for euer haplesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Cle.
SP.L: But take time,
The second thoughts our wise men say are best.

SP.SPEAKER: Pli.
SP.L: Delaye's a double death, no I haue thought
A meanes, that straight Ile put in execution,
Ile write a Letter to her presently,
Take how it will.

SP.SPEAKER: Cle.
SP.P: A Letter, who shall carry it?

SP.SPEAKER: Pli.
SP.P: Ile tell thee when I haue done, hast thou Pen and Inke in thy Chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Cle.
SP.P: Yes, there is one vpon the Table, Ile stay here at the window, and watch whether she stay or not, what a sud∣den change is this.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: Did not count Virro promise to be heare
To day at dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Pse.
SP.L: Yes Madame that he did, and I dare sweare
He will not breake.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: He needes not, he is rich enough, vnlesse
Hee should breake in knauery, as some of our Mhants doe now adayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Pse.
SP.L: Breake promise Madame I meane, & that he will not
For your sake, you know his businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: I would I did not, he might spare his paines
And that vnusuall cost, that he bestowes
In pranking vp himselfe, and please me better
He would not please his Taylor and his Barbar,
For they got more for your sake by their Lord
Then they got this twenty yeeres before.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: Ah Psecas, Psecas, can my father thinke
That I can loue Count Virro, one so old
(That were enough to make a match vnfit)
But one so base, a man that neuer loued
For any thing called good, but drosse and pelfe,
One that would neuer, had my brother liued
Haue mooued this sute, no I can neuer loue him,
But canst thou keepe a secret firmely Psecas.

SP.SPEAKER: Pse.
SP.P: Doubt me not Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: Well Ile tell thee then,
I loue, alas, I dare not say I loue him,
But there's a yong and noble Gentleman,
Lord Euphues sonne, my fathers enemy.
A man whom natures prodigality
Stretcht euen to enuy in the making vp,
Once from a Window my pleased eye beheld
This youthfull Gallant as he rode the streete,
On a coruetting Courser, who it seemed
Knew his faire loade, and with a proud disdaine
Checkt the base earth, my father being by
I ask't his name, he told me Philocles,
The sonne and Heyre of his great enemy:
Iudge Psecas then, how my deuided brest,
Suffered betweene two meeting contraries,
Hatred and Loue, but Loues a deity,
And must preuaile against mortals, whose command
Not oue himselfe could euer yet withstand.

SP.SPEAKER: Cle.
SP.P: What is the letter done already, I see these Louers haue nimble inuentions, but how will you send it.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: What a question's that, seest thou this stone.

SP.SPEAKER: Cle.
SP.L: Ah, then I see your drift, this stone must guide your
Fleeting Letter in the Ayre, and carry it to that
Faire Marke you ayme at.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Hard by her.

SP.SPEAKER: Cle.
SP.L: I think you would not hit her with such stones as this,
Lady looke to your selfe, he that now throwes one
Stone at you, hopes to hit you with two.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: But prethee tell mee what doest thinke this Letter may doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cle.
SP.L: Well I hope,
Tis ten to one this Lady oft hath seene you,
You neuer liued obscure in Syracuse,
Nor walk'd the streetes vnknowne, and who can tell
What place you beare in her affections,
Lou'd or mislik'd; if bad, this letter sent,
Will make her shew her scorne, if otherwise,
Feare not a womans wit, sheele find a time
To answere your kind Letter, and expresse
What you desire she should, then send it boldly,
You haue a fairer make there.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Cupid guide my arme,
Oh be as iust blind God as thou art great,
And with that powerfull hand, that golden shaft
That I was wounded, wound you tender brest,
There is no saluē but that, no cure for me,

SP.SPEAKER: Cle.
SP.P: See what a wonder it strikes vm in, how it should come.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Sheele wonder more to see what man it comes from.

SP.SPEAKER: Cle.
SP.L: I like her well, yet she is not afraid to open it:
She starts, stay marke her action when shee has read the Letter.

LETTER.L: "LEt it wrong this Letter that it came,
"From one that trembled to subscribe his name,
"Fearing your hate, O let not hate descend,
"Nor make you cruell to so vow'd a friend,
"If youle not promise loue, grant but accesse,
"And let me know my woes are past redresse,
"Be iust then beautious Iudge, and like the lawes
"Condemne me not till you haue heard my cause,
"Which when you haue, from those faire lips returne
"Either my life in loue, or death in scorne.

SP.L: Am I awake or dreame I, is it true
Or does my flattering fancy but suggest
What I most couet.

SP.SPEAKER: Pse.
SP.L: Madame the words are there,
Ile sweare it canna be, nor be illusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.P: It is too good for truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Mocke me not fortune,
She kist it, sawest thou her, by heauen she kist it.

SP.SPEAKER: Cle.
SP.L: And with a looke that relisht loue, not scorne,

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.P: This Letter may be forged, I much desire to know the certainty, Psecas thy helpe must further me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pse.
SP.P: Ile not be wanting.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.P: Here comes my father, he must not see this.

SP.SPEAKER: Pse.
SP.P: No nor your tother sweet heart, hee is with him yonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Nay noble Count you are too old a Souldier
To take a maides first no, for a deniall,
They will be nice at first, men must pursue
That will obtaine, woe her my Lord and take her,
You haue my free consent if you can get hers,
Yonder she walkes alone, goe comfort her.

SP.SPEAKER: Virro
SP.L: Ile doe the best I may, but we old men
Are but cold comfort, I thanke your Lordships loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: I wonder Roscio that the peeuish Girle
Comes on so slowly on peswasions
That I can vse, do mooue the setting forth
Count Ʋirroes greatnesse, wealth and dignity
Seemes not to affect her, Roscio.

SP.SPEAKER: Roscio.
SP.L: I doubt the cause my Lord,
For were not that, I dare ingage my life,
She would be wonne to loue him, she has plac'd
Already her affections on some other.

SP.SPEAKER: Poli.
SP.L: How should I find it out

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.L: Why thus my Lord
Theres neuer man nor woman that ere loued,
But chose some bosome friend whose close conuerse,
Sweeten their ioyes, and ease their burdened minds
Of such a working secret, thus no doubt
Has my yong Lady done, and but her woman,
Who should it be, tis she must out with it,
Her secrecy if wit cannot orereach,
Gold shall corrupt, leaue that to me my Lord,
But if her Ladies heart doe yet stand free
And vnbequeath'd to any, your command
And fathers iurisdiction enterpos'd
Will make her loue the Count, no kind of mne
must want to draw her.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Thou art my Oracle,
My Braine, my Soule, my very being Roscio,
Walke on and speede whilst I but second thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Cle.
SP.L: It is euen so, Count Ʋirro is your riuall,
See how the old Ape smugs vp his mouldy chap
To seize the bit.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: He must not if I liue,
But yet her father brings him that has the meanes
That I should euer want.

SP.SPEAKER: Cle.
SP.L: If he do marry her
Reuenge it nobly, make him a Cuckold boy,

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Thou iests that feeles it not, prithee lets goe,

SP.SPEAKER: Cle.
SP.L: Stay, Ile not curse him briefely for thy sake,
If thou doest marry her mayest thou be made
A Cuckold without profit, and nere get
An Office by it, nor fauour at the Court,
But may thy large ill gotten treasury
Be spent in her bought lust, and thine owne gold
Bring thee adulterers, so farewell good Count.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.L: My Lord, ther's a Messenger within
Desires accesse, has businesse of import,
Which to no eare but yours he must impart.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: Admit him, now friend, your businesse with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: If you be the Lord Polimetes.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: The same.

SP.SPEAKER: Euge.
SP.L: My Lord, I come from Athens with such newes
As I dare say is welcome though vnlooked for,
Your sonne Eugenio liues whom you so long
Thought dead and mourn'd for.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: How, liues.

SP.SPEAKER: Euge.
SP.L: Vpon my life my Lord I saw him well
Within these few dayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Thankes for thy good newes,
Towards him Roscio, but now tell me frend
Hast thou reueal'd this newes to any man
In Syracuse but me.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: To none my Lord,
At euery place where I haue staid in towne,
Enquiring for your Lordships house, I heard
These tragicke, but false newes, the contrary
I still conceald, though knew, intending first
Your Lordships eare should drinke it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Worthy fiend.
I now must thanke your wisedome as your loue
In this well carried action, Ile requite it,
Meane time pray vse my house, and still continue your
Silence in this businesse, Roscio make him welcome, and
Part as little from him as you can for feare.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.P: Thinke it done, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: Psecas come hither.

SP.L: Be like your selfe, let not a cruell doome
Passe those faire lips, that neuer were ordain'd
To kill, but to reuiue.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: Neither my Lord
Lyes in the power to doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: Yes sweete to me.
Whom your scorne kils, and pitty will reuiue.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.P: Pitty is shew'd to men in misery.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.P: And so am I, if not relieu'd by you.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.P: Twere pride in me, my Lord, to thinke it so.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.P: I am your beauties captiue.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: Then my Lord,
What greater gift then freedome can I giue,
Tis that that Captiues most desires, and that
You shall command, y'are free from me my Lord,

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.P: Your beauty contradicts that freedome Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: come noble Count, I must for this time interrupt you
You'le finde time enough within to talke.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋir.
SP.P: Ile wait vpon your Lordship. exeunt manet Euge. solus.

SP.SPEAKER: Euge.
SP.L: Thus in disguise I haue discouer'd all,
And found the cause of my reported death,
Which did at first amaze me, but tis well,
Tis to draw on the match betweene my sister
And this rich Count, heauen grant it be content
As well as fortune to her, but I feare
She cannot loue his age, how it succeedes
I shall perceiue, and whilst vnknowne I stay,
I cannot hurt the proiect, helpe I may. Exit.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: This will make good worke for you in the spirituall
Court, Shallow is a rich man.

SP.SPEAKER: Sum.
SP.L: I marry Sir,
Those are the men we looke for, ther's somewhat
To be got, the Court has many businesses at this
Time, but they are little worth, a few waiting
Women got with child by Seruingmen or so, scarce
Worth the citing.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Do not their Masters get
Vm with child sometimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sum.
SP.L: Yes no doubt, but
They haue got a trick to put vm off vpon their
Men, and for a little portion saue their
Owne credits; besides, these priuate marriages
Are much out of our way, we cannot know when
There is a fault.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: Well, these are no
Starters I warrant you, Shallow shall not deny it,
And for the Wench she neede not confesse it, she hs
A marke that will betray her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sum.
SP.L: I thanke you
Sir for your good intelligence, I hope tis certaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Franc.
SP.P: Feare not that, is your citation ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Sum.
SP.P: I haue it heere.

SP.SPEAKER: Franc.
SP.P: Well step aside, and come when I call, I heare vm comming. Exit Sumner.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Set forward there, Francisco what make you here.

SP.SPEAKER: Franc.
SP.L: I come to claime my right, Parson take heede,
Thou art the Author of adultery
If thou conioyne this couple, shee's my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: you saucebox.

SP.SPEAKER: Shal.
SP.P: Father, I thought she had beene mine, I hope I shall not loose her thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: Francisco, dare not to interrupt vs, for I sweare thou shalt endure the lawes extremity
For thy presumption.

SP.SPEAKER: Franc.
SP.L: doe your worst, I feare not,
I was contracted to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: What witnesse haue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Franc.
SP.P: Heauen is my witnesse, whose imperiall eye saw our contract.

SP.SPEAKER: Shal.
SP.P: What an Asse is this to talke of con∣tracting, hee that will get a wench, must make her big∣ger as I haue done, and not contract.

SP.SPEAKER: Franc.
SP.P: Sir, you are abus'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Shal.
SP.P: Why so.

SP.SPEAKER: Franc.
SP.P: The wife you goe to marry is with child, and by another.

SP.SPEAKER: Shal.
SP.P: A good iesty faith, make me beleeue that.

SP.SPEAKER: Franc.
SP.P: How comes this foole possest, he neuer toucht her I dare sweare.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: No more Francisco as you will answere it,
Parson set forward there.

SP.SPEAKER: Franc.
SP.L: stay,
If this will not suffice, Sumner come forth.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: A Sumner, we are all betraid. Enter Sumner.

SP.SPEAKER: Sum.
SP.L: God saue you all, I think you guesse my businesse,
These are to cite to the spirituall Court
You master Shallow, and you mistresse Luce,
Aske not the cause, for tis apparant here,
A carnall copulation, ante matrimonium.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: This was a barre vnlookt for, spitefull Francisco

SP.SPEAKER: Franc.
SP.L: Iniurious Franklin, could the lawes diuine,
Or humane suffer, such an impious act,
That thou shouldst take my true and lawfull wife,
And great with child by me, to giue t'another,
Gulling his poore simplicity.

SP.SPEAKER: Shal.
SP.P: Do you meane me Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sum.
SP.P: Gallants Farewell, my writ shall be obeyd.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Summer it shall. exit Summer

SP.SPEAKER: Par.
SP.L: Ile take my leaue, theres nothing now for me to do

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Farewell good master Parson. exit Parson

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: Francisco canst thou say thou euer louedst my daughter, and wouldst thou thus disgrace her openly.

SP.SPEAKER: Franc.
SP.L: No, I would win her thus,
And did you hold her credit halfe so deare
As I, or her content, you would not thus
Take her from me, and thrust her against her will
On this rich foole.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.P: You are very bold with me Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Franc.
SP.P: Let me haue newes what happens dearest Luce.

SP.SPEAKER: Luc.
SP.P: Else let me die. exit Francisco.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: This was your doing Luce, it had beene
Vnpossible he should ere haue knowne the time
So truly else, but Ile take an order next time
For you babling.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.P: Whats the matter father.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: We may
Thanke you for it, this was your haste that will
Now shame vs all, you must be doing a fore your
Time.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.L: Twas but a tricke of youth father,

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: And threrefore now you must eene stand in a
White sheete for all to gaze at.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.L: How,
I would be loath to weare a surplesse now, tis a
Disgrace the house of the Shallowes neuer knew▪

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: All the hope is, officers may be brib'd, and so they will, twere a hard world for vs to liue in else.

SP.SPEAKER: Shal.
SP.P: You say true father, if twere not for corruption, e∣uery poore rascall might haue iustice as well as one of vs, and that were a shame. exeunt Shal. Luce

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.L: This was a cunning stratagem well layd,
But yet Francisco th'hast not won the prize:
What should I do, I must not let this cause
Proceed to tryall in the open Court,
For then my daughters oath will cast the child
Vpon Francisco: no, I haue found a better,
I will before the next Court day prouide
Some needy Parson, one whose pouerty
Shall make him feare no Cannons, he shall marry
My daughter to rich Shallow, when tis done
Ou gold shall make a silence in the Court. Exit▪

SP.SPEAKER: Pse.
SP.L: I must returne your answere to my Lady,
He tell her you will come.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Come,
And such a Angell call, I should forget
All Offices of Nature, all that men
Wish in their second thoughts, ere such a duty
Commend my seruice to her, and to you
My thankes for this kind Message. exit Psecas.
I neuer breath'd till now, neuer till now now
Did my life relish sweetenesse, breake not heart,
Cracke not yee feeble Ministers of nature
With inundation of such swelling ioy,
To great to beare without expression:
The Lady writes that she has knowne me long
By sight, and lou'd me, and she seemes to thanke
Her starres she loues, and is belou'd againe,
She speake my very thoughts, by heauen tis strange
And happy when affections thus can meete;
She further writes at such an houre to day,
Her fathers absence, and all household spis
Fitly remoou'd, shall giue accesse to me
Vnmarkt to visit her, where she alone
Will entertaine discourse and welcome me.
I hope tis truely meant, why should I feare,
But wisedome bids me feare: fie, fie, tis base,
To wrong a creature of that excellence,
With such suspicion I should iniure her,
I will as soone suspect an angell false,
Treason neare lodg'd within so faire a brest,
No, if her hand betray me, I will will runne
On any danger, tis alike to me
To dye, or find her false, for on her truth
Hangs my chiefe being, well Ile lose no time
No not a minute, dearest loue I come,
To meete my sweetest wishes I will flye,
Heauen and my truth, sheild me from trechery. Exit.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus Tertius.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: I Cannot credit it, nor thinke that she
Of all the noble youth in Sicilly,
Should make so strange a choise, that none but he,
None but the sonne of my vow'd enemy
Must be her mate, it strikes me to amaze,
Minion take heede, doe not belie your Mistresse.

SP.SPEAKER: Pse.
SP.L: Mercy forsake me if I doe my Lord,
You charg'd me to confesse the truth to you,
Which I haue fully done, and presently
Ile bring you where conceal'd, you shall both see
Their priuacy and heare their conference.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Well I beleeue thee wench, and will reward
Thy trust in this, goe get thee in againe
And bring me word when Philocles is come,
Sir youle be secret to our purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Euge.
SP.P: As your owne breast my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: I shall rest thankfull to you:
This stranger must be soothd lest he marre all.

SP.SPEAKER: Rosc.
SP.P: This was well found out my Lord, you now haue meanes to take your enemie.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: With blest occasion I will so pursue
As childlesse Euphes shall for euer rue.
Rise in thy blackest looke direst Nemesis
Assistant to my purpose, helpe m glut
My thirsty soule with blood. This bold yong man
To his rash loue shall sacrifice his life.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: What course you intend, to ruine him.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: Why kill him presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Ro.
SP.L: Oh no my Lord,
Youle rue that action, thinke not that the Law
Will let such murther sleepe vnpunished.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Should I now let him goe now I haue caught him

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: Yes Sir, to catch him faster, and more safely.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: How should that be? speake man.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.L: Why thus my Lord;
You know the law speakes death to any man
That steales an Heire without her friends consent,
This must he do, his loue will prompt him to it,
For he can neuer hope by your consent
To marry her, and she tis like will giue
Content, for womens loue is violent,
Then marke their passage you shall easly find
How to surprise them at your will my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Thou art my Oracle deare Roscio,
Heres Psecas come againe; how now what newes?

SP.SPEAKER: Pse.
SP.P: My Lord they both are comming please you with∣draw, you shall both heare and see what you desire.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: Ye are welcom Noble Sir and did my power,
Answere my loue your visitation,
Sould be more free, and your deserued welcome
Exprest in better fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Best of Ladies,
It is so well, so excellently well,
Comming from your wisht loue, my barren thanke
Wants language for't, there lies in your faire lookes
More entertainement then in all the pompe
That the vaine Persian euer taught the world,
Your presence is the welcome I expected,
That makes it perfect.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: Tis your noble thought
Makes good whats wanting here, but gentle friend,
For so I now dare call you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Tis well Minion you are bold
Enough I see to chuse your friends without my leaue.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Tis my ambition euer to be yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: Thinke me not light, deare Philocles, so soone
To grant thee loue, that others might haue sought
With eagerest pursuit, and not obtain'd,
But I was yours by fate, and long haue beene,
Before you wood Leucothoe was wonne,
And yours without resistance.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Oh my Starres
Twas your kind influence, that whist I slept
In dullest ignorance, contriu'd for me
The way to crowne me with felicity.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: You may be deceiu'd though,
You haue no such great reason
To thanke your Starres if you knew all.

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: And know faire Mistresse you haue met a loue,
That time, nor fate, nor death can euer change,
A man that but in you can haue no being:
Let this kisse seale my faith.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.P: And this mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: Nay too't againe, your sweete meate shall haue sowre sawce.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: But sweet, 'mongst all these Roses ther's one thorne
That prickes and galls me, our parents enmity
Will crosse our loues, I doe assure my sonne
This father neuer will giue his consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: No so I thinke, he moues me still to Virro
That old craz'd Count, and with such vehemency
I dare scarce bide his presence if I deny him;
Therefore we must be speedy in our course,
And take without his leaue what he denyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: I thanke you for that good daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.P: I told you Sir twould come to this at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Oh thou hast spoke my wishes, and hath shewd
Thy selfe in loue as true as beautifull;
Then let's away dearest Leucothoe,
My fortunes are not poore, then feare no want,
This constant loue of ours may proue so happy,
To reconcile our parents enmity.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.P: Heauen grant it may.

SP.SPEAKER: Po.
SP.P: Neuer by this meanes yongster.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.P: But soft now I thinke better ont Ile not goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Why dearest, is thy loue so quickly cold?

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: No, but ile not venter thee, thine is the danger,
Thou knowest tis death by law to steale an heire,
And my deare brothers most vntimely death,
Hath lately made me one, what if thou shouldst be taken.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Oh feare not that, had I a thousand liues,
They were too small a venture for such prise,
I tell thee sweete, a face not halfe so faire
As thine, hath arm'd whole actions in the field,
And brought a thousand ships to Tenedos,
To sacke lamented Troy, and should I feare
To venture one poore life, and such a life
As would be lost in nor possessing thee:
Come come, make that no scruple, when shall we goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: This present euening, for to morrow morning
My father lookes that I should giue consent
To marry with the Count,

SP.SPEAKER: Phil.
SP.L: Best of all, would twere this present houre,
Ile goe prepare, but shall I call thee heere.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.P: Oh no, weele meete.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Where dearest.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: East from the City by a Riuers side,
Not distant halfe a mile there stands a groue,
Where often riding by I haue obserued
A little Hermitage, there I will stay
If I be first, if you, doe you the like,
Let th'houre be ten, then shall I best escape.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Nere sweeter comfort came from Angels lips
I know the place, and will be ready there
Before the houre: Ile bring a friend with me
As true as mine owne heart, one Clerimont,
That may doe vs good if danger happen.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.P: Vse your pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Dearest farewell,
Houres will seeme yeeres till we are met againe. exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Ah Sirrah, this geere goes well, god a mercy girle
For thy intelligence, why this is as much as a
Man could desire, the time, place, and euery thing;
I warrant vm they passe no further, well
Goe thou in and wait vpon thy Mistresse, shees
Melancholly till she see her sweete heart againe, but
When shee does, shee shall not see him long,
Not a word of whats past among vs for your life.

SP.SPEAKER: Pse.
SP.P: I warrant you my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Ile not so much as shew an angry looke,
Or any token that I know any of their proceedings,
But Rosio, we must lay the place strongly, if they
Should scape vs, I were pritily fool'd now after all
This.

SP.SPEAKER: Ros.
SP.L: Why tis impossible my Lord, weele goe
Strong enough, besides I thinke it fit we tooke
An Officer along with vs to countenance it the
Better.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Thou sayst well, goe get one,
Ile goe my selfe along with you too, I loue
To see sport though I am old, you'le goe
Along with vs to Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: I Sir, you shall
Command my seruice when you are ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Now Euphues, what I did but barely act
Thy bleeding heart shall feele, losse of a sonne
If Law can haue his course, as who can let it,
I know thou think'st mine dead, and in thy heart
Laughest at my falling house, but let them laugh
That winne the prize, things nere are knowne till ended.

SP.SPEAKER: Eug.
SP.L: Well I like my sisters choise, she has taken a man
Whose very lookes and carriage speake him
Worthy, besides he is Noble, his fortunes sufficient,
They both loue each other, what can my father
More desire, that he gapes so after this old
Count▪ that comes for the estate, as tother vpon
My soule does not, but pure spotlesse loue, but
Now his plot is for reuenge vpon his old enemy:
Fye, Fye tis bloudy and vnchristian, my soule
Abhors such acts, this match may rather
Reconcile our houses, and I desire where worth
Is to haue friendship, as on my soule tis there.
Well Philocles I hope to call thee brother.
Somewhat Ile doe, Ile goe perswade Count Ʋirro
Not to loue her, I know the way, and Ile but
Tell him truth her brother liues, that will
Coole his loue quickly; but soft, here comes
The Count as fit as may be.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋir.
SP.L: She loues me not yet, but that's no matter,
I shall haue her, her father sayes I shall,
And I dare take his word, maides are quickly
Ouer-rul'd, ah, ah, me thinkes I am growne yonger
Then I was by twenty yeeres, this Fortune
Cast vpon me, is better then Medeas charme, to
Make an old man yong againe, to haue a
Lords estate freely bestowed, and with it such
A beauty as should warme Nectors bloud,
Make old Priam lusty. Fortune I see thou louest me
Now, Ile build a Temple to thee shortly, and
Adore thee as the greatest deity. Now what are you.

SP.SPEAKER: Euge.
SP.L: A poore Scholler my Lord, one that
Am little beholding to Fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋir.
SP.L: So are most of your profession,
Thou shouldst tke some more thriuing
Occupation, to be a iudges man, they are
The brauest now adayes, or a Cardinals
Pander, that were good profession and gainefull.

SP.SPEAKER: Euge.
SP.P: But not lawfull, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋerro.
SP.L: Lawfull,
That Cardinall may come to be Pope, and
Then he could pardon thee and himselfe too.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: My Lord I was brought vp a Scholler.
And I thanke your counsell, My
Lord, I haue some for you, and therefore I
Came.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.P: For me, what I prithee.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.P: Tis weighty and concernes you neere.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.P: Speake, what ist?

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.P: My Lord, you are to marry old Polimetes Daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.P: And Heire.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: No Heire
My Lord, her Brother is aliue.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.P: How, Thou art mad.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: My Lord,
What I speake is true, and to my knowledge
His father giues it out in pollicy to marry his
Daughter the better, to hooke in sutors, and
Specially aym'd at you, thinking you rich
And couetous, and now he has caught you.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.P: But dost thou mock me.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Let me be euer miserable if I speake
Not truth, as sure as I am here Eugenio liues,
I know it, and know him, where he is.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.P: Where prithee.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Not a daies iourney hence,
Where his father enioyn'd him to stay till your
Match, and sends word to him of this plot:
Besides, I ouer-hard the old Lord and his man
Roscio, laughing at you for being caught thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: Why, wert thou at the house then.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Yes, But had scuruy entertainment
Which I haue thus reueng'd

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: Beshrew my heart I know not what
To thinke on't, til like enough, this Lord was
Alwayes cunning beyond measure, and it
Amaz'd me that he should grow so exreme
Kind to me on the suddaine to offer me all this:
Besides this fellow is so confident, and on
No ends of couznage that I can see; well,
I would faine enioy her, the Wench is
Delicate, but I would haue the estate too, and
not be guld, what shall I doe, now braines
If euer you will, helpe your Master.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: It stings him.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: Well, so, Sir,
What may I call your name?

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Irus my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: Your name as well as your attire
Speakers you poore.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: I am so.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: And very poore.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Very poore.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: Would you not gladly take a course
To get money, and a great some of mony.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Is gladly if your Lordship would but
Shew me the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: Harke ye.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Oh my Lord, Conscience.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: Fye, neuer
Talke of the Conscience, and for Law thou art
Free, for all men thinke him dead, and
His father will be ashamed to follow it
Hauing already giuen him for dead,
And then who can know it, come be wise,
Fiue hundreth crownes Ile giue.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Well, tis pouerty that does it, and not I,
When shall I be paid.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: When thou hast done it.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Well giue me your
Hand for it my Lord

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: Thou shalt.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: In writing, to be paid when I haue
Poysoned him, and thinke it done.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: Now thou
But loue has made me bold, the time has beene,
In such a place as this I should haue fear'd
Each rowling leafe, and trembled at a reed
Stird in the Mooneshine, my fearefull fancy
Would frame a thousand apparisions,
And worke some feare out of my very shadow:
I wonder Philocles is tardy thus,
When last wee parted euery houre, he said,
Would seeme a yeere till we were met againe,
It should not seeme so by the hast he makes
Ile sit and rest me, come I know he will.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: This Clerimont this is the happy place
Where I shall meet the summe of all my ioyes,
And be possest of such a treasury
As would inrich a Monarch.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: This is his voyce,
My Philocles.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: My life, my soule, what here before me,
Oh thou dost still out goe me, and dost make
All my endeauours poore in the requitall
Of thy large fauours, but I forget my selfe.
Sweete bid my friend here welcome, this is he
That I dare trust next mine owne hearth with secrets.
But why art thou disguised thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: I durst not venture else to make escape.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Euen now me thinkes I stand as I would wish
With all my wealth about me, such a loue
And such a friend, what can be added more
To make a man liue happy, thou darke groue
That hast beene cald the seat of Melancholy,
And shelter for the discontented spirits;
Sure thou art wrong, thou seemst to me a place
Of solace and content, a Paradise
That giuest me more then euer Court could doe
Or richest Palace, blest be thy faire shades,
Let birds of musicke euer chant it heere,
No croking Rauen, or ill booding Owle
Make heere their balefull hahitation
Frighting thy walkes, but mayst thou be a groue
Where loues faire Queene may take delight to sport:
For vnder thee two faithfull Louers meet,
Why is my faire Leucothoe so sad.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.P: I know no cause, but I would faine be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Whether sweete.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: Any whether from hene.
My thoughts diuine of treason, whence I know not,
There is no creature knowes our meeting heere
But one, and thats my maid, she has beene trusty
And will be still I hope, but yet I would
She did not know it, prithee lets away
Any where else, we are secure from danger.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Then lets remoue, but prithee be not sad.
What noise is that.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.P: Ay me.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Oh feare not Loue. draw.

DIV2.STAGE: Eer Polimedes, Roscio, Eugenio and Officers.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: Vpon vm Officers, yonder they are.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Theeues, Villaines.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Thou art the Thiefe and the Villaine too,
Giue me my Daughter thou rauisher.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: First take my life.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Vpon vm I say. fight.
Knocke vm downe Officers if they resist, they are taken.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: Oh they are lost, ah wicked, wicked Psecas;

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P:
So keepe vm fast, weele haue vm faster shortly, and for you Minion, Ile tye a clog about your neck for run∣ning
away any more.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.P: Yet do but heare me father.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Call me not father thou disobedient wretch,
Thou Run-away, thou art no child of mine,
My Daughter nere wore Breeches.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: Oh Sir, my Mother would haue done as much
For loue of you, if need had so required,
Thinke not my mind transformed as my habite.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Officers away with vm, peace Stumpet,
You may discharge him, he's but an assistant.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: Oh stay and heare me yet, heare but a word
And that my last it may be, doe not spill
The life of him in whom my life subsists,
Kill not two liues in one, remember Sir,
I was your Daughter once, once you did loue me,
And tell me then, what fault can be so great,
To make a father murtherer of his child,
For so you are in taking of his life.
Oh thinke not Sir that I will stay behinde him
Whilst there be Aspes, and Kniues, and burning Coles▪
No Roman dame shall in her great example
Outgoe my loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: Oh where will sorrow stay,
Is there no end in griefe or in my death
Not punishment enough for my offence,
But must her griefe be added to afflict me;
Dry vp those Pearles dearest Leucothoe,
Or thou wilt make me doubly miserable,
Preserue that life, that I may after death
Liue in my better part, take comfort deare,
People would curse me, if such beauty should
For me miscarry, no, liue happy thou,
And let me suffer what the law inflicts.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: My offence was as great as thine,
And why should not my punishment.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Come haue you done, Officers away with him.
Ile be your keeper, but Ile looke better to you.
But Rosie you and I must about the businesse:
sir let it be your charge to watch my Daughter,
And see she send no message any whither,
Nor receiue any.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: It shall my Lord. exeunt manet Eu. and Leu.
Ile be an Argus, none shall come heere I warrant you,
My very heart bleedes to see two such louers so
Faithfully parted so. I must condemne my father,
Hees too cruell in this hard action, and did not
Nature forbid it, I could raile at him, to reake
His long fostred malice against Lord Euphues thus
Vpon his sonne, the faithfull louer of his owne
Daughter, and vpon her, for should it come to passe
As he expects it shall, I thinke t' would kill her
Too, she takes it —: See in what strange amazement
Now she stands, her griefe has spent it selfe so
Farre that it has left her sencelesse, it greeues
Me thus to see her, I can scarce forbeare reuealing
Of my selfe to her, but that I keepe it for a
Better occasion when things shall better answere to
My purpose: Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.P: What are you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: In that my Lord your father has appointed
To giue attendance on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: On me, alas I neede no attendance,
He might bestow his care better for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: I came but lately to him, nor doe I meane
Long to stay with him, in the meane time Lady
Might I but doe you any seruice.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.P: All seruice is too late, my hopes are deseperate.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Madame, I haue a feeling of your woe,
A greater your owne brother could not haue,
And thinke not that I come suborn'd by any
To vndermine your secrets, I am true,
By all the gods I am, for further tryall
Command me any thing, send me on any message
Ile doe it faithfully, or any thing else
That my poore power can compasse.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: Oh strange fate
Haue I lost pitty in a fathers heart,
And shall I find it in a stranger: Sir
I shall not liue to thanke you, but my prayers
Shall goe with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Tis not for thankes or neede
But for the seruice that I owe to vertue
I would doe this.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: Surely this man
Is nobly bred, how ere his habite giue him:
But Sir, all physicke comes to me too late,
There is no hope my Philocles should liue▪

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Vnlesse the King were pleasd to grant his pardon,
Twe're good that he were mou'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: Ah who should doe it,
I feare me tis in vaine, Count Virro
And my father both will crosse it, but I would venture
If I could get but thither.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Thats in my power
To giue you liberty, your father left me
To be your keeper, but in an act
So meritorious as this, I will not hinder you,
Nay I will waite vpon you to the Court.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: A thousand thankes to you, well ile goe,
Grant oh you powers aboue, if Virgins teares,
If a true loues prayers had euer power
To moue compassion grant it now to me,
Arm'd with so strong a vigor, my weake words
They may pierce deepe into his kingly brest,
And force out mercy in spite of all opposers.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.P: Come lets away. exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.L: MY dearest Luce, were thy old Sire as iust
As thou art truely constant, our firme loue
Had neuer met these oppositions,
All my designes as yet, all practises
That I haue vs'd, I see are frustrated,
For as my faire intelligencer writes,
He will before the next court day prouide
Some carelesse person▪ that in spite of lawes
Shall marry her to Shallow, this being done,
He meanes to hold the Couts seuerity
To by a golden bit, and so he may,
Al it is too true, I must preuent it,
And that in time, before it grow too farre;
But how, there lies the point of difficulty:
But what strange sight is this that greetes mine eyes,
Alphonso my old Captaine, sure tis he.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.L: Thus once againe from twenty yeares exile,
Tost by the stormes of fortune too and fro,
Has gratious heauen giuen me leaue to tread
My natiue earth of Sicily and draw
That aire that fed me in my infancy.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.L: Tis he, most noble Captaine, oh what power
Has bene so gratious as to blesse mine eyes
Once more with sight of my most honored master.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.L: Kind yuth the teares of ioy that I haue spent
To greet my natiue country haue quite robd
Mine eyes of moysture, and haue left me none
To answer thy affection, but tell me,
Tell me how thou hast liu'd in Syracuse
These fiue yeeres here, since that vnluckly storme
Diuided vs at Sea.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.L: Faith poorely Sir,
As one that knows no kindred nor alliance,
Vnknowne of any haue I shifted out,
But I haue heard you say that I was borne
In Syracuse, tell me what stocke I come of,
What parentage, how meane so ere they be,
They canno well be poorer then my selfe,
Speake, do you know them Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.L: Yes very well,
And I am glad the fates haue brought me home,
For thy deare sake, that I may now disclose
Thy honorable birth.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: Honorable?

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.L: Yes noble youth, thou art the second sonne
To old Lord Euphues, a man more worthy
And truly noble neuer drew this ayre;
Thy name's Lysandro, this discouery
Will be as welcome to your friends as you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.P: You do amaze me Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.L: Ile tell you all,
It was my fortune, twenty a yeare ago,
Vpon the Tyrrhene shore, whose sea diuides
This Ile from Italy, to keepe a fort
Vnder your noble father, where your selfe
Then but a child, was left to my tuition,
When sodainly the rude assailing force
Of strong Italian Pirats so preuaild,
As to surprisall of the fort and vs.
Your name and noble birth I then conceald,
Fearing some outrage from the enmity
Of those fell Pyrates, and since from your selfe
I purposely haue kept the knowlenge of it.
As loath to grieue your present misery
With knowledge of what fortunes you had lost,
That this is true, you straight shall see th'effect,
Ile goe acquaint your father with the tokens,
And make his oreioyde heart leape to embrace
Thee his new found and long forgotten sonne:

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.L: Worthy Captaine, your presence was alwayes
Welcome to me, but this vnlookt for newes, I
Cannot suddenly disgest.

SP.SPEAKER: Al.
SP.P: Well Ile go to him presently. exit Alphonso.

SP.SPEAKER: Fr.
SP.L: Now my deare Luce, I shall finde meanes to quite
Thy loue, that couldst descend so low as I
When I was nothing, and with such affection,
This was my suit still to the powers aboue,
To make me worthy of thy constant loue.
Exit Francisco. But ile about the proiect I intended.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: Why now my Lord you are neerer to her loue then euer you were yet, your riuall by this accident shall be re∣moued out of the way, for before the scorneful girle would neuer fancy any man else.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.P: I conceiue you Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: I labourd it for your sake as much as for my
Owne, to remoue your riuall and my enemy, you
Haue your loue, and I haue my reuenge.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: I shall liue my Lord to giue you thankes, but aside.
T'will be after a strange manner, if Irus has
Dispatched what he was hired too, then my kind
Lord I shall be a little too cunning for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: My Lord you are gracious with the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋir.
SP.P: I thanke his Maiesty, I haue his care before ano∣ther man.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: Then see no pardon be granted, you may stop any thing; I knew Euphues will be soliciting for his sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.P: I warrant you my Lord no pardon passes whilst I am there, ile bee a barre betwixt him and the King, but hearke the King approaches.

SP.SPEAKER: Ambo.
SP.P: Health to your Maiesty.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Count Virro, and Lord Polimetes welcome,
You haue beene strangers at the Court of late;
But I can well excuse you Count, you are about a wife,
A yong one and a faire one too they say,
Get me yong souldiers Count, but speake
When is the day, I meane to be your guest,
You shall not steale a martiage.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋir.
SP.P: I thanke your Maiesty, but the marriage that I intended is stolen to my hand, and by another.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.P: Stolne, how man.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: My promised wife
Is lately stolne away by Philocles,
Lord Euphues sonne against her fathers will,
Who followed vm and apprehended them,
The Law may right vs Sir, if it may haue course.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.P: No reason but the law should haue his course.

SP.SPEAKER: Euph.
SP.P: Pardon dread Soueraigne, pardon for my sonne.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.P: Your sonne, Lord Euphues, what is his offence.

SP.SPEAKER: Euph.
SP.L: No hainous one my Leige, no plot of treason
Against your royall person or your state,
These aged cheekes would blush to beg a pardon
For such a foule offence, no crying murder
Hath steyned his innocent hands, his fault was loue,
Loue my deare Leige, vnfortunately he tooke
The Daughter and Heire of Lord Polimetes,
Who followes him and seekes exstremity.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: I seeke but Law, I am abus'd my Leige,
Iustice is all I beg, my Daughters stolne,
Staffe of my age, let the law doe me right,

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: To his iust prayers doe I bend my knee
My promised wife is stolne, and by the sonne
Of that iniurious Lord, iustice I craue.

SP.SPEAKER: Euph.
SP.L: Be like those powers aboue, whose place on earth
You represent, shew mercy gracious King,
For they are mercifull.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Mercy is but the Kings prerogatiue,
Tis Iustice is his office, doing that
He can wrong no man, no man can complaine,
But mercy shewed oft takes way reliefe
From the wronged partie that the Law would giue him:

SP.SPEAKER: Eup.
SP.L: The Law is blind and speakes in generall termes,
She cannot pitty where occasion serues,
The liuing law can moderate her rigour,
And thats the King.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: The King I hope in this will not do so,

SP.SPEAKER: Eup.
SP.L: Tis malice makes thee speake,
Hard hearted Lord, hadst thou no other way
To wreake thy cankred and long fostred hate
Vpon my hed but thus, thus bloudily
By my sonnes suffering, and for such a fault
As thou shouldst loue him rather, is thy daughter
Disparaged by his loue, is his blood base,
Or are his fortunes sunke, this law was made
For such like cautions, to restraine the base
From wronging noble persons by attempts
Of such a kind, but where equality
Meetes in the match, the fault is pardonable.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.P: Mercy my Soueraigne, mercy gratious King.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Minion who sent for you, twere more modesty
For you to be at home.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Let her alone, speake Lady,
I charge you no man interupt her. Enter Leucothoe

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: If euer pitty toucht that princely brest,
If euer Virgins teares had power to moue,
Or if you euer lou'd and felt the pangs
That other louers doe, pitty great King,
Pitty and pardon two vnhappy Louers.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.P: Your life is not in question.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: Yes royall Sir
If Law condemne my Philocles, he and I
Haue but one heart, and can haue but one fate.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.P: Excellent vertue thou hadst not this from thy father.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Ther's Musicke in her voice, and in her face
More then a mortall beauty▪ Oh my heart,
I shall be lost in passion if I heare her,
Ile heere no more, conuey her from my presence,
Quickly I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.P: This is strange.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: I told you what he would doe, I knew
He would not here of a pardon, and I against it,
He respects me.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: No doubt he does my Lord▪
I like this passage well.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: But stay,
Stay Lady, let me heare you, beshrew my heart
My minde was running of another matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: Where the diuell hath his minde bin all this while,
Perhaps he heard none of vs neither,
We may eene tell our tales againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: No sure he heard vs, but tis very strange.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Tis such a tempting poison I draw in,
I cannot stay my draught, rise vp Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: Neuer vntill your graces pardon raise me,
Ther's pitty in your eye, oh shew it Sir,
Say Pardon gracious King, tis but a word
And short, but welcome as the breath of life.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Ile further here the manner of this fact,
Auoid the presence all, all but the Lady,
And come not till I send.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: I like not this.

SP.SPEAKER: Ʋir.
SP.P: Nor I here is mad dancing.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Heauen blesse thy sute thou mirror of thy sex,
And best example of true constant loue,
That in the Sea of thy transcendent vertues
Drown'st all thy fathers malice, and redeem'st
More in my thoughts then all thy kin can lose. exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Now Lady what would you doe to saue the life
Of him you loue so deerely.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: I cannot thinke that thought I would not doe,
Lay it in my power, and beyond my power
I would attempt.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: You would be thankefull then
To me if I should grant his pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: If euer I were thankefull to the gods
For all that I call mine, my health and being,
Could I to you be vnthankefull for a gift
I value more then those, without which
These blessings were but wearisome.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Those that are thankefull study to requite
A courtesie, would you doe so? would you requite
This fauour▪

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: I cannot Sir,
For all the seruice I can doe your Grace
Is but my duty, you are my Soueraigne,
And all my deedes to you are debts not merits,
But to those powers aboue that can requite,
That from their vastlesse treasures hope rewards,
More out of grace then merrit on vs mortals,
To those ile euer pray that they would giue you
More blessings then I haue skill to aske.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.P: Nay but Leucothoe, this lies in thy power to re∣quite, thy loue will make requitall, wilt thou loue me?

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: I euer did my Lord.
I was instructed from my infancy,
To loue and honour you my Soueraigne.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.P: But in a neerer bond of loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: There is no neerer nor no truer loue
Then that a loyall subiect beares a Prince.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Still thou wilt not conceiue me▪ I must deale plain
With you, wilt thou lye with me, and I will seale his
Pardon presently; nay more, ileheape vpon you
Both all fauours, all honours that a Prince can giue.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: Oh me vnhappy, in what a sad dilemma stands my choise.
Either to lose the man my soule most loues,
Or saue him by a deed of such dishonour
As he will euer loath me for, and hate
To draw that breath that was so basely kept.
Name any thing but that to saue his life,
I know you doe but tempt my frailty Sir,
I know your royall thoughts could neuer stoope
o such a soule dishonourable act.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Bethinke your selfe, there is no way but that,
I sweare by Heauen neuer to pardon him
But vpon those conditions.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.P: Oh I am miserable.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Thou art not if not wilfull, yeeld Leucothoe,
It shall be secret, Philocles for his life
Shall thanke thy loue, but neuer know the price
Thou paidst for it; be wise thou heardst me sweare,
I cannot now shew mercy, thou maist saue him,
And if he dye, tis thou that art the Tyrant.

SP.SPEAKER: Leu.
SP.L: I should be so if I should saue him thus,
Nay I should be a Traytor to your grace,
Betray your soule to such a foe as lust,
But since your oath is past, deare Philocles
Ile shew to thee an honest cruelty,
And rather follow thee in spotlesse death,
Then buy with sinning a dishonoured life.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Yet pitty me Leucothoe, cure the wound
Thine eyes hath made, pitty a begging King,
Vncharme the charmes of thy bewitching face,
Or thou wilt leaue me dead: will nothing moue thee,
Thou art a Witch, a Traytor, thou hast sought
By vnresisted spels thy soueraignes life:
Who are about vs there, call in the Lords againe,
Lord Poltes, take your daughter to you,
Keepe her at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: I will my Leige, Rosio see her there I wonder what is done.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Euphues I haue tane a solemne oath
Neuer to grant a pardon to thy snne.

SP.SPEAKER: Euph.
SP.L: O say not so my Leige, your grace I know
Has mercy for a greater fault then this.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.P: My oath is past and cannot be recalled.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: This is beyond our wishes.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.P: What made him sweare this I wonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Euph.
SP.L: A heauy oath to me and most vnlooked for,
Your iustice Sir has set the period
Vnto a loyall house, a Family
That haue bin props of the Sicylian crowne,
That with their blouds in many an honourd field,
Gainst the hot French, and Neopolitan
Haue seru'd for you and your great Ancestors,
Their children now can neuer more doe so,
Farewell my Soueraigne, whilest I in teares
Spend the sd reman of my childlesse age,
Ile pray for your long life and happy raigne,
And may your Grace and your Posterity
At neede finde hands as good and hearts as true
As ours haue euer beene.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.P: Farewell good old man.

SP.SPEAKER: Eup.
SP.L: For you my Lord, your cruelty has deseru'd
A crse from me, but I can vtter none,
Your Daughters goodnesse has weigh'd down your malice
Heauen prosper her.

SP.SPEAKER: Poly.
SP.P: Amen.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: He is an honest man and truely noble,
Oh my rash oath, my lust, that was the cause,
Would any price would buy it in againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Vi.
SP.P: Your Maiesty is iust.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.L: Tis a happy Land
Where the King squares his actions by the law.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Away, you are base and bloudy,
That feedes your malice with pretence of iustice,
Tis such as you make Princes tirranous,
And hated of their subiects, but looke too't,
Looke your owne heads stands fast for if the law
Doe finde a hole in your coates, beg no mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.P: Pardon vs my Lord, we were wrong'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: And sought redresse but by a lawfull course.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.P: Well leaue me alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.P: Fare well my Leige, now let him chafe alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Pol.
SP.P: Now we haue our ends. exeunt.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Is there no meanes to saue him no way,
To g a dispensation for an oath,
that I know except the Court of Rome
Will grant one, thats well thought on,
I will not spare for gold, and that will doe it,

SP.SPEAKER: Nica.
SP.P: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: What booke is that
Thou hadst from Paris about the price of sinnes.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Tis cald the Texes of the Apostolicall Chancery.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.P: Is there a price for any sinne set downe.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: A my Sir, how heinous ere it be,
Or of what nature, for such a summe of money
As is set downe there, it shall be remitted

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.P: Thats well, go fetch the book presently. exit Nic.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: I will my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Sure there is periury
Among the rest, and I shall know what rate
It beares before I haue committed it.
How now hast brought it.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: Yes Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Reade, I would know the price of periury,

SP.SPEAKER: Nic
SP.P: I shall find it quickly, heres an Index. he reads Imp. For murder of all kinds of a Clergy man, of a lay man, of father, mother, Sonne, brother, sister, wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.P: Reade till you come at periury.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Item, for impoysoning, enchantments, witchcraft,
Sacriledge, simony, and their kind and
Branches. Item, pro lapsu carnis, fornication
Adultery, incest without any exception or
Distinction; for sodomy, Brutality, or any of
That kind.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: My heart shakes with horror
To heare the names of such detested sinnes,
Can these be bought for any price of money,
Or do these merchants but deceiue the world
With their false Wares▪ no more of that foule booke,
I will know what I came to know,
I would not for the world redeeme my oath
By such a curse as this, no more Nicanor
Vnlesse thou finde a price for Atheisme.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Heres none for that my Lord, his Holinesse
Can pardon that in no man but himselfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Kin.
SP.L: Well this is not the way,
I haue thought of another that may proue,
And both discharge my oath and saue his life,
Nicanor run presently, call Matho hither,
Matho the Lawyer, command him to make hast,
I long to be resolued.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.P: I runne Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: He is a subtill Lawyer, and may find
Some point, that in the Lawes obscurity
ee hid from vs, some point may doe vs good,
I haue seene some of his profession
Out of case as plaine, as cleere as day
To our weake iudgements, and no doubt at first
Meant like our thoughts by those that made the Law,
Picke out such hard inextricable doubts,
That they haue spun a suit of seuen yeere long,
And leade their hood winke Clients in a wood,
A most irremoueable Labyrinth,
Till they haue quite consum'd vm, this they can doe
In other cases, why not as well in this.
I haue seene others could extend the Law
Vpon the wrack, or cut it short againe
To their owne priuate profits, as that thiefe
Cruell Procrustes seru'd his haplesse guests,
To fi them to his bed; Well I shall see,
I would Nicanor were returned againe,
I would faine ease my conscience of that oath,
That rash and inconsiderate oath I tooke,
But see, heere they are comming. Enter Matho.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.P: Health to my Soueraigne.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Matho, welcome.
I sent for thee about a businesse
I would intreate thy helpe in.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.L: Your Highnesse may command my seruice
In that, or any thing lies in my power.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.P: Tis to decide a case that troubles me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
