SP.L: If it lye within the compasse of my knowledge,
I will resolue your Highnesse presently.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Then thus it is, Lord Euphues sonne,
Yong Philocles, has lately stolne away
The Daughter and Heire of Lord Polimetes,
Who is his enemy, he following him hard
Has apprehended him, and brings him to his tryall
To morrow morning: thou hast heard this newes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.L: I haue my Liege, and euery circumstance
That can be thought on in the businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.P: And what will be the issue by the Law.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.L: He must dye for it, the case is plaine,
Vnlesse your grace will grant his pardon.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: But can there be no meanes thought vpon
To saue him by the Law.

SP.SPEAKER: Matho.
SP.P: None my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Surely there may, speake man, Ile giue thee
Double Fees.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.P: It cannot be my Leige, the Statutes is plaine.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Nay now thou art too honest, thou shouldst do
As other Lawyers doe, first take my mony,
And then tell me thou canst doe me good.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.L: I dare not vndertake it, could it be done,
Ide goe as farre as any man would doe.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Yes if twere to cut a poore mans throat you could,
For some rich griping Land-lord you could grin'd
The face of his poore Tenant, stretch the Law
To serue his turne, and guided by his Angels,
Speake Oracles more then the tongues of men,
Then you could find exceptions, reseruations,
Stand at a word, a silible, a letter,
Or coine some scruples out of your owne braines,
But in a cause so full of equity
So charitable as this, you can find nothing,
I shall for euer hate all your profession.

SP.SPEAKER: Ma.
SP.L: I do beseech your Highnesse to excuse me,
I cannot doe more then your lawes will let me,
Nor falsifie my knowledge nor my conscience.

SP.SPEAKER: King.
SP.L: Then I am miserable, rise Matho rise,
I do not discommend thy honesty,
But blame my owne hard fate, ay Philocles
I would redeeme thy life at any price,
But the Starres crosse it, cruell fate condemnes thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Come fellow watchmen, for now you are my fellowes,

SP.SPEAKER: Watch.
SP.P: I pleases you to call vs so master Constable.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: I do it to encourage you in your office, it is a tricke that we commanders haue, your great Captains call your souldiers fellow souldiers to encourage them.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Watch.
SP.P: Indeed and so they do, I heard master Curate trading a story booke tother day to that purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Well I must shew now what you haue to do, for I my selfe before I came to this prefermity, was as simple as one of you, and for your better destruction, I will deride my speech into two parts. First, what is a watchman. Se∣condly, what is the office of a watchman. For the first, fany man aske me what is a watchman, I may answer him, he is a man as others are, nay a tradesman, as a Vintner, a Tayler, or the like, for they haue long bils.

SP.SPEAKER: . Wat.
SP.P: He tels vs true neighbour, we haue bils indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: For the second, what is his office; I answer, he may by vertue of his office reprehend any person, or persons, that wlke the streets too late at a seasonable houre.

SP.SPEAKER: 4. Wat
SP.P: may we indeed master Constable.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Nay, if you meet any of those rogues at seasonable houres, you may by vertue of your office commit him to prison, and then aske him whither he was going.

SP.SPEAKER: . Watch.
SP.P: Why thats as much as my Lord Maior does.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: True, my Lord Maior can doe no more then you in that point.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Wat.
SP.P: But master constable what if hee should resist vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Why if he do resist, you may knocke him downe, and then id him stand, and come afore the Constable. So you are sufficiently cnstructed concerning you office take your stands, you shall heare rogues wal∣king at these seasonable houres, I warrant you, stand close.

SP.L: Purpose, now doe I take as much care to be apprehended,
As others doe to scape the watch, I must speake
To be ouerheard, and plainly too, or els these dolts
Will neuer conceiue mee.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Harke who goes by?

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.P: Oh my conscience, my conscience, the teror of a Guilty conscience.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: How, conscience talkes hee of,
He's an honest man, I warant him, let him passe

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Wa.
SP.P: I I, let him passe, good night honest gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: These are wise officers, I must bee plainer yet.
That gold, that cursed gold, that made me poison him
Made me poison Eugenio.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: How made me poison him, he's a knaue I warrant him.

SP.SPEAKER: 3. Wa.
SP.L: M. Constable has found him already,

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: I warant you a knaue cannot passe me, go reprehend him, Ile take his excommunication my selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Wa.
SP.L: Come afore the constable

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Wa.
SP.P: Come afore the Constable.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Sirrah, sirrah, you would haue scap'd
Would you, no sirrah you shall know the Kings
Officers haue eyes to heare such roagues as you,
Come sirrah, confesse who it was you poison'd, he
Lookes like a notable roague.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Wa.
SP.L: I dooe not like
His lookes.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Wa.
SP.P: nor I.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: You would deny it
Would you sirra, we shall sift you,

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: Alas master

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: I cannot now deny what I have said
You ouer heard me, I poisoned Eugenio sonne to
Lord Polimetes.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Wa.
SP.P: Oh rascall.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Wa.
SP.L: my
Young Landlord.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Let him alone, the law
Shall punish him, but sirra where did you poison
Him.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.L: About a dayes iourney hence, as he was
Comming hom from Athens I met him, and
Poisoned him.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: But sirrah who set you a worke
Confesse, I shall finde out the whole ne of there
Rogues, speake.

SP.SPEAKER: Eu.
SP.P: Count Virro hired me to do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Oh lying Rascall.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Wat.
SP.P: Nay he that will steale will lye.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Wat.
SP.P: Ile beleeue nothing he sayes.

SP.SPEAKER: 3. Wat.
SP.P: Be lye a man of worship.

SP.SPEAKER: 4. Wat.
SP.L: A noble man

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.L: Away with him, Ile heare no more, remit him to
Prison; Sirrah, you shall heare of these things
To morrow, where you would be loath to heare vm.
Come lets goe. exeunt.

DIV2.HEAD: Actus quintus.
DIV2.STAGE: Enter Franklin, Shallow, Luce, Francisco in a Parsons habit, and a true Parson otherwise attyred.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: ILe take your counsell Sir, Ile not be seene in't, but meete you when tis done, youle marry them.

SP.SPEAKER: Fran.
SP.P: Feare not that Sir, Ile doe the deede.

SP.SPEAKER: Frank.
SP.P: I shall rest thankfull to you, till then Ile leaue you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sha.
SP.P: I pray father leaue vs, wee know how to behaue our selues alone, mee thinkes Luce wee are too many by two yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Luce.
